content.description: Distinct crux sections on this traverse are encountered going into and coming out of both the central and west alcoves. Each alcove provides options to either remain low and underneath a roof, or reach out of the roof and climb the lip/roof edge. All options end high and work back down on 5.10+ terrain. It is possible to traverse from left to right, but the standard traverse starts upstream and traverses to the left. For a true endurance test, try the out-and-back.
content.protection: Maybe a pad or spotter. Landings are on flat rock.
content.location: Upstream of Mosquito Bridge. The start is marked by a large boulder, climber's right of the bridge cracks.

content.description: The classic badass Mosquito Pump.  Led by Don Garrett in 1976 or 77 with hexentrics.  The must do route here.  Goes from fingers to hands to fist to small off-width in forty feet.
content.location: The awesome straight in and up crack directly beneath the bridge.

content.description: Two ways to start: can sit start in the cave and V2 it out to the chockstone (big stemming), or work the feet up the crack just left of the bottom of the cave till you can reach onto the chockstone and pull into it.  Then, brutal jamming to a cave, then over the roof to the top.
content.location: About 25 feet right of Twist and Shout, is the Susan Forever Cave.  Object is to get to the chockstone on the lip of the cave and then thrash your way straight to the top.

content.description: Start in the pea pod and finger jam, thin and flared, over the roof.  Proceed up into a corner and on to the top.  Very smooth stone and slippery jams.
content.location: Just right of Susan Forever Cave, on the outside, is a thin finger crack with a pea pod down low.  Follow this wicked finger job to the top.

content.description: From the top of the big boulder on the right side of Coral Cove, grab the rail and mantle onto the slab (5.10a). Move up the slab into a rotten, dirty, vegetation-filled off-fist crack (the crux). Climb the crack to the boulder at the top and exit right.
content.protection: A pair of sunglasses or safety goggles to keep the dirt out of your eyes. Top rope from a very old pair of bolts on a boulder directly above the climb.

content.description: Boulder the overhang (the crux) and arrive on a slab. Move right into a right-facing layback crack (first opportunity for pro). Move up the crack and mantle onto another slab. From here, either follow the left-hand crack system to the top (often dirty, but good options for pro), or choose the no-pro slab to the right. This is a good first 5.11, as the crux occurs in the first two moves.
content.location: Directly to the left of Hangtown, on the obvious overhang.

climbs.name: Octopus' Gardens
climbs.fa: late 70s by Don Garrett and Ron Vardanega

content.description: Both cracks 10a/b, just the right crack 5.10c/d.
content.location: Located in The Octopus Garden, under the main roof. Right of the two bolted routes.

content.description:
Just as you should never judge a book by its cover, you should also never judge a climb by the amount of moss growing next to it.

Sustained liebacking persists until gaining the ledge. From here, climb a short thin-hands crack to the chains. Despite the amount of moss that often grows next to this climb, the crack itself is usually clean. A great climb.
content.location: The right-most crack at the Bridge Crack area. Look for the wide, left-leaning crack that is often mossy.

content.description: Handjams and liebacking with glassy feet lead to an alcove. From here, jam the left-hand crack to the top of the formation.
content.location: This diagonal crack starts just to the left of the West Alcove and trends left toward the bottom of the bridge.

content.description: Big pulls on overhanging terrain into slippery slab for the last 2/3 of the route.
content.protection: While the bottom of the route can be protected with finger-sized cams, the upper slab has no opportunities for pro. Running it out would make this 5.10x. Can be toproped by crossing over the guardrail north of the bridge and carefully following the path of least resistance to the top of Boot Flake.
content.location: On the arete that divides the Coral Cove and Boot Flake areas.

content.description: The easiest route at Mosquito Coast. Dirty crack with secure hand jams. Watch out for the forest of poison oak above the anchors.
A bouldery, overhung start leads to steep edges on a clean headwall. Climb to the left of a thin seam that opens up and becomes flared at the anchor.
content.protection: While this route might go on gear...it makes more sense to toprope it. Be safe when setting up a toprope on this climb, as the bolts are in a slick location.
content.location: To the right of The Boot. The first free climb at the Boot Flake Area that is reached when approaching from upstream.

content.description:
If you're ever there with an hour or so to kill, this little bouldering circuit is pretty decent.  This isn't well covered in Cottrell's guide so I'll run through what I like.  These problems were worked out in the 70s/80s by a group of Placerville climbers: Bob Branscomb, Don Garrett (by far THE MAN here), Kim Treadaway, and Ron Vardanega.

See Will Cottrell's Rock Climbs of Placerville guide for over all picture.

Start in Octopus' Gardens area, do the V0 traverse both ways from Octos Gardens to Golden Road a few times.  Then the start to Her Cheeks, V0 to the chockstone.  Boulder the 5.10+ start to Reluctant Elevation, drop off with care.  Go to Susan Forever, do the V2 stemming grunt(sit start)to the chockstone on the lip, drop off with care (fall into river potential here).  Do the V1 traverse (sit start)from Susan Forever to Straight Lines.  Attempt the V2 run from Susan Forever to Sickle Ledge (sit start), drop off with care. Sickle Ledge is an inobvious crimp above the Susan Forever Cave, right of that crack. Boulder the start of Bush Whack (sit start) to the jug on the right, drop off.  Do the right to left traverse from the boulder below Mr. Mustard to Bush Whack (V1 to V3 depending on low or high through cave), and continue either to Straight Lines (V2) or up Bush Whack to jug.  Do Talk is Cheap (V1 or V2) to the Bush Whack jug, drop.  There's a short no hands slab (9) on the south side of the boulder below Mr. Mustard.  Boulder the 5.9 mantel problem on the right side of a boulder under the trees half way bewteen Mr. Mustard and Antline.  Do the three 5.9-5.10a face problems to the right of Antline.

Something to do here besides jamming yourself to death.
content.protection: Bouldering pad is almost a must...some hard landings otherwise.
content.location: Base of the Mosquito Bridge and on the face right of Antline.

content.description: Bouldery start keeps the pressure on until the "toe" of the Boot Flake is attained. From the toe of the flake, continue up and left on 5.9+ terrain.
content.protection: With an attentive belayer/spotter, the start of this route can be bouldered until the off-fingers crack to the left of the Boot Flake is reached. From here, you'll need pro to 1". Boot Licker can also be top roped by scrambling down the hill from the road north of the bridge. A .75" cam can be used as a directional.

content.description: Don't be fooled by the easy opening move off of a big jug...The rest of the route is sustained quarter to half-pad crimps on a slightly overhung face. A tricky top-out keeps things interesting to the very end.
content.protection: Pad(s) and a spotter to move the pad(s), or toprope from a pair of bolts above the Antline crack and be on the ready for a swing.
content.location: Starts on the largest jug on the face to the left of the Antline crack.

content.description: A classic finger jamming exercise.  Very fun with an interesting ending.
content.location: This is the obvious, aesthetic finger crack on the rock up the river from the main area.  There are top rope anchors on top, reachable from a gulley on the right side of the rock.
